ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This was one of the best classes I have taken at FES. It did a great job of incorporating science, policy, and management on one topic.

The course was very interesting and the professor did a great job of using different styles of teaching, with a great blend of discussion, writing, presentation style, exams, and quizzes. The professor was also flexible in his teaching style and even asked for a course evaluation mid-course. The course also offered a lot of breadth in the course material. I didn't feel that all of the homework assignments were very conducive to my learning. The expectations for the final projects were too high and the feedback was harsh. The quizzes were also very difficult.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The individual assignment and the field trips

Shimi is an expert on the topic, namely at tying management with science. This is the kind of thinking that the business and environmental communities demand, and Shimi elicits great thinking form his students.
Shimi is one of the best teachers at FES. He does a great job explaining the material and answering questions.
The general overview, we also had a lot of time to get to know our fellow classmates.
Professor is very engaging and covers range of topics well in a way that caters to different learning styles
The material was very interesting and covered so many different topics which was great.

For me the best aspects of this course came through the useful application of technical water resource science and engineering concepts to policy and management decisions. This approach led to a deep understanding of various water challenges ranging from water supply and quality to issues like flooding. However, the blending of technical and management focuses also introduced a variety of strategies for addressing these challenges. I also appreciated the input from other students in the class. Shimi does an excellent job of encouraging productive and pertinent discussion amongst the students in the class. Also, since each student has a different background related to water, the diverse perspectives provide a valuable learning component to the course.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The class discussions, but its sort of the nature of the beast since it's mostly a bunch of like-minded individuals talking to each other.
The farm field trip seemed less relevant.

I think some of the economic concepts (specifically game theory) could be better explained. At times, it was hard to keep up the workload for the class. Also, it would have been helpful to have a rubric for some of the assignments so we were aware what we were being graded on in advance.
More guidance and help on writing the paper for the class- it was very open ended and there was minimal feedback, but the grading scheme- which was never provided- was difficult.

The feedback and expectations on the final paper were unrealistic and caused me stress rather than allowed me to learn. Also I'm not sure how much consideration was put into the difficulty in the material and subject that students were choosing in their papers and how that could affect their feedback. Some topics were clearly more complex and difficult than other topics and I'm not sure if this was taken into account.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Supports my interest in corporate sustainability by giving me a very solid understanding of all related water issues.
My background in environmental policy helped me in sections of this course but the ability to connect the science to policy and economics as well as management was really helpful.
A great step for anyone interested in water resources.

As an MESc. student with research projects focused on stormwater management, flooding, and water quality this course provided a valuable link between my research and the management implications of my findings. This translation of science to management was also valuable to me since I came into the course with an engineering background and therefore had a fairly firm understanding of the technological aspects of water management but less familiarity with the policy side of these issues. Therefore it was helpful to see how legislation, regulation, and general management decisions tie into the application of the engineering and science focuses on water resources. Also, my work prior to taking this course was largely focused on urban stormwater management. Since this was only a small part of the course, it was valuable to broaden my understanding of water resources to encompass other sectors such as water supply, agriculture, and industry.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Interest in the subject material; requirement for track
I want to be a water resource manager and I felt this was necessary to understand the range of problems and potential solutions.

I took this course for mainly two reasons: 1. My research focuses on water resources and I intend on pursuing a career in water resources engineering. FES 712 provided an applied and holistic understanding of the issues that I am researching while also introducing other important considerations that will be pertinent to my career moving forward. 2. Shimi is one of the best professors with whom I have had the pleasure of taking a course (both undergrad and grad). The passion he has for the material is palpable and it leads to active class discussions and a wonderful learning environment.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: No, I had a solid background in water before this course and I did not find a lot of information new
Absolutely yes.
Yes, it was very helpful. It would be great if there was a follow up course to this one so we could build on what we learned.
Yes! Definitely take it!
Yes
Yes, the course met all expectations with regards to bridging the gap between my technical engineering background and the application to policy and management.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take shimi's warning seriously - this is mostly a survey course on water issues.
I would highly recommend this course to students interested in water, land use, and/ or agriculture. I think it does a great job at covering a wide range of topics.
Make sure you have the time to put into the course, it is totally worth it.
Be prepared to learn a lot of very interesting and useful material but know that this course is very demanding and requires a lot of time, energy, and dedication.
Definitely take it! It will be one of the best classes you take at FES!
